info.title: Per Angusta API
info.description:
Per Angusta API was first released in 2017 to support the growth of the partnerships and the need to strengthen data exchanges.
It has a secured authentication process based on two well known web standards: OAuth and JWT.
Its design was largely inspired by the JSON API specification.

OAuth2.description: Per Angusta API implements the « Client Credentials » grant of the protocol OAuth 2.0 to authorize third-party clients from accessing protected resources.

tags.name: authentication
tags.description:
In every requests, you need to pass a Bearer Token in the `Authorization` header in the form of `Authorization: Bearer <token>`.

For instance, with curl you should use it like that:

```bash
curl -G -X GET https://staging.per-angusta.com/api/v3/suppliers \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>'
```

tags.name: pagination
tags.description:
The number of resources returned in a response is limited by a page-based strategy. The maximum number of resources per page is 500 and there is no limit of number of pages.

Parameters:
- `page[number]` Page number, by default “1”
- `page[size]` Number of resources per page, default value depending on the endpoint

To help you traverse a paginated data set, the primary object “links” available at the root of the response contains up to 4 links as described below:
- `first` If current page number is different than “1”, contains a link to the first page
- `prev` If current page number is different than “1”, contains a link to the previous page
- `next` If current page number is different than the last available page number, contains a link to the next page
- `last` If current page number is different than the last available page number, contains a link to the last page

The primary object “meta” available at the root of the response contains following information:
- `page_number` Current page number
- `page_size` Current page size
- `total_pages` Number of available pages
- `total_count` Total number of resources that can be traversed through pagination

Example of request with pagination options:
```
curl -G -X GET  https://staging.per-angusta.com/api/v3/suppliers \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' \
  -d 'page[number]=2&page[size]=30'
```

Example of primary object “links”:
```
{
  "links": {
    "first": ".../api/v3/suppliers?page[number]=1&page[size]=30",
    "prev": ".../api/v3/suppliers?page[number]=1&page[size]=30",
    "next": ".../api/v3/suppliers?page[number]=3&page[size]=30",
    "last": ".../api/v3/suppliers?page[number]=20&page[size]=30"
  }
}
```

Example of primary object “meta” with pagination data:
```
{
  "meta": {
    "page_number": 2,
    "page_size": 30,
    "total_pages": 20,
    "total_count": 582
  }
}
```

tags.name: sorting
tags.description:
You can ask for a different sorting of data sets using the parameter “sort”. It may accept a list of whitelisted attributes, separated by a comma “,”. The list of available attributes depends on the endpoint. If you don’t specify the direction, default is “ascending order”, it may be specified by using “+” (ascending) or “-“ (descending) in front of the attribute name.

Parameters:
- `sort` By default “-updated_at” (sort by last modification date in descending order)

The primary object “meta” available at the root of the response contains following information:

- `sort` Current sort options

Example of request with sorting option “by name in ascending order and by last modification date in descending order”:
```
curl -G -X GET  https://staging.per-angusta.com/api/v3/suppliers \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' \
  -d 'sort=+name,-updated_at'
```

Example of primary object “meta” with sorting data:
```
{
  "meta": {
    "sort": "-updated_at"
  }
}
```

tags.name: filtering
tags.description:
Filtering allows you to filter data sets. At the time of writing this documentation, only the “free text search” filtering option is available.

Parameters:
- `filter[q]` Free text search

Example of request using free text search:
```
curl -G -X GET  https://staging.per-angusta.com/api/v3/suppliers \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' \
  -d 'filter[q]=xyz'
```

tags.name: end_user_policy
tags.description:
Data sets can differ depending on the permissions of the authenticated End-User. By default, the policy which is applied is the “read” policy. If you are building a user interface to create objects through the API, you may want to filter data sets with “write” policy.

It won’t have any effect in case of Client authentication without specified “email”.

Parameters:
- `policy[mode]` By default “read”, may be set to “write”

The primary object “meta” available at the root of the response contains following information:
- `policy_mode` Current policy mode

Example of request using “write” policy:
```
curl -G -X GET https://staging.per-angusta.com/api/v2/objects/budgets \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' \
  -d 'policy[mode]=write'
```

Example of primary object “meta” with policies data:
```
{
  "meta": {
    "policy_mode": "read"
  }
}
```

tags.name: rate_limits
tags.description:
The maximum number of requests that are allowed is based on a time interval, some specified period or window of time.

The most common request limit is **200 requests per 60 seconds**, but some endpoints may have their own constraints.

Use the HTTP headers in order to understand where the application is at for a given rate limit, on the method that was just utilized.
- `X-RateLimit-Limit`: the maximum nb of requests per period
- `X-RateLimit-Remaining`: the remaining allowed requests in current period
- `X-RateLimit-Reset`: the remaining window before the rate limit resets, in UTC epoch seconds

When an application exceeds the rate limit for a given endpoint, the API will return a HTTP 429 “Too Many Requests” response code, and the following error will be returned in the response body:

```
{ "error": { "code": 50429, "message": "You have reached the limit of 200 requests per time window. Please wait 17 second(s) before trying to access the application again." } }
````

patch.description: Create or update a batch of suppliers. In the case of an update, it will only update missing attributes (soft update).

parameters.name: email
parameters.description:
In case of authenticated End-User, do not specify this parameter\
                                                                    In case of authenticated Client, specify End-User’s email

parameters.description: Budget ID to which you would like to associate the supplier

parameters.description: Axes configured on this object as a key value pair. The key being the id of the applicable axis (as a 'String'). The value being the value OR the id of the available option for this axis (if it's of type 'select')

400.description: Batch error, all records are rolled back

get.description: Obtain a brief summary about phases.
Obtain a brief summary about a supplier.

post.description: Import data in batch with the "DataSource" interface. The result of that endpoint is an array of batch import operations, depending on the maximum number of lines per template. The rate limit is 2 requests per 30-second interval.

parameters.name: email
parameters.description:
In case of authenticated End-User, do not specify this parameter\
                                                                In case of authenticated Client, specify End-User’s email

parameters.name: data_source[data_source_type]
parameters.description: Type of the data_source (e.g. Supplier). Please refer to the templates endpoint for more information on available types.

parameters.name: data_source[data][]

get.description: Retrieve details and status of an import

patch.description: Interact with visitors' session (sign in, sign out, impersonation, etc.)

download_url.description: Document's download url. Expiring time: 3600 seconds.

file_tag.description: File tag the asset belongs to

description.example: Wayne corp. is a nice company.

custom_fields.description:
Every axis configured on this object will appear as a key value pair here.
The key being the 'id' of the applicable axis (as a String).
The value being an Object containing the following fields:
* 'value' (String) contains either the content of the custom_field, or the 'id' of the available option (if the type is 'select').
* 'field_type' (String) contains the type of the custom_field (numeric, date, text, string, select, select_multiple) configured in the axis.
* 'field_name' (String) is a human readable version of the name of the custom field
* 'mandatory' (Boolean) defines if the axis is mandatory
* 'is_archived' (Boolean) tells you if the available option is archived (boolean) (only if the field_type is 'select')
* 'value_human' (String) is a human readable version of the selected option (only if the field_type is 'select')

message.example: An error occurred while creating suppliers

legal_identifier.description: Unique supplier identifier sent on request

error_messages.description: Keys are the attributes where the error occurred, values are arrays of strings describing the error
